title: If someone travels to and from another planet, will they age differently than Earth comparatively? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a question about the Twins Paradox - first proposed by Einstein - twin brothers - one takes off in a ship and achieves a relativistic speed, and when he returns. his brother is twelve years older Of the 50+ solutions to this, each has a number of refutations including the most recent one - jump-frames - which is naive when you think about it A pattern emerges in each solution however, in that - in their attempt to prove Einstein was correct, they don’t actually use Einstein in their solution - they appeal to something else - denying Einstein- ironic, no? Einstein used a phrase “mutatis mutande” concerning frames of reference with motion - and motion alone - to explain things - this means each frame of reference is independent to all others - and the observer in one frame experiences the same events equally to all others for example: If I’m on a platform watching a train approach, I consider myself stationary while the train is in motion - but - if I’m on the train - I can consider myself stationary while the platform is in motion - it’s all in the frame of reference of the observer Back to the Twins Paradox - If I’m the brother in the spaceship, I can consider myself in motion and my brother stationary- or - my brother can consider himself in motion and the spaceship stationary - it’s all in the observer’s frame of reference Can you tell from the above which brother would age faster? Of course not, and neither could Einstein- that’s why it’s a paradox To the OP’s question - no - the possibilty one will age faster is based on the observer, so neither will age faster The more folks try to solve this paradox the more they realize they’re defending a crackpot Einstein received the Nobel for the photoelectric effect, not for Relativity Then, as now, a wide range of scientists can explain what we see without Einstein, and the only reason Einstein burst on the scene was largely political and public-relations- even his assistants claimed he was a shoddy mathematician “That light requires the same time to traverse the path A→M as for the path B→M is in reality neither a supposition nor a hypothesis about the physical nature of light, but a stipulation which I can make of my own free will in order to arrive at a definition of simultaneity.” -Albert Einstein, “Relativity ...”, chapter 8, “ On the idea of time in physics ”,1916 In the above, we see that Einstein didn’t actually measure the speed of light as constant- he stipulated it - as a convention Conventions are like English and Metric - both are accurate within their models - and choosing one over the other does not produce “wrong” measurements What if we had a different convention for the speed of light? It would resolve a lot of anomalies we see today, such as quantum entanglement speed has a formula: speed = distance/time But Einstein claimsd that time is relative. If we agree with Einstein, the above equation yields a relative value for the speed of light - and we deny Einstein’s constant speed of light If we declare light speed constant, then time must be constant, and we deny Einstein’s assertion of relative time Many experiments and measurements on the speed of light have been gathered over the last century, and one trend is significant to all this - the speed of light is measured as slower with each new measurement. How can this be if the speed of light is constant?

It’s not the travelling - it’s the speed. If they travel slowly, there will not be a difference, or it will be so small as to not matter in any meaningful way. If they can get to a decent percentage of the speed of light, they will start appearing to age slower compared to someone on Earth. The closer they get to the speed of light, the larger the effects.
